executive_summary: Grocery wholesalers act as a middleman between food producers and retailers. Improving per capita disposable income has allowed consumers to trade up to more expensive options at grocery stores or switch to dining out. Grocery wholesalers benefit either way as they distribute products to both markets. However, the growing trend of eliminating the middleman has pressured revenue expansion during the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The intense foot traffic at grocery stores and food service outlets highlights the indispensable role of grocery wholesalers as critical components of food supply networks. Enhanced economic conditions and a strengthening number of households have supported industry revenue despite industry revenue slightly shrinking.

During the pandemic, grocery wholesalers endured substantial challenges because of supply chain disruptions, capacity reductions or temporary closures of significant customers, such as sports stadiums, restaurants and schools. These disruptions further fueled the industry's consolidation trend, allowing large enterprises to seize a larger market share and navigate the crisis more effectively.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE TREND TOWARDS ELIMINATING THE MIDDLEMAN SUBDUES EXPANSION
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A significant challenge for grocery wholesalers' growth is the trend of bypassing wholesalers in the supply chain, as grocery producers and retailers expansively collaborate directly to eliminate the middleman. With wholesalers holding less sway in the grocery supply chain, many have struggled to negotiate favorable prices with large manufacturers, weakening their bargaining power.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An Increasing Focus on Healthy and Sustainable Products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As consumer preferences change, a boosted focus on health and sustainability has emerged as a critical trend impacting grocery wholesalers over the past five years. Wholesalers are diversifying their product offerings to include organic, gluten-free, eco-friendly options to cater to health-conscious consumers and environmentally aware retailers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Grocery Wholesalers Will Expansively Cater to the Customer
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition intensifies, wholesalers must explore innovative ways to set themselves apart from their rivals. These include tapping into niche markets and launching new formats catering to expanding communities. The rising demand for ethnic foods presents a promising opportunity for grocery wholesalers to target these specialized markets and foster relationships with ethnic food manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Private-Label Products Will Swell in Grocery Wholesaling
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Expanding private-label products will be a substantial trend in the industry, driven by strengthening consumer demand for affordable yet quality alternatives to name-brand products. Wholesalers must expand their private-label offerings and continuously innovate to cater to their retail partners' and customers' diverse needs, seeking value for money without compromising quality.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand From Food Service Will Support Expansion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wholesalers will see revived demand from food service customers as per capita disposable income strengthens and businesses return to entire operations. Savvy wholesalers will reposition themselves to capture new restaurant and food service customers since these outlets will form an expansion portion of the industry's customer base.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Boosted Competition May Pose a Threat
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Retail chains with their distribution facilities will swell in number and size. Self-distributing retailers can shift more products per hour in their warehouses than the average third-party wholesaler. Competition among grocery wholesalers will continue to intensify over the next five years as companies compete for a smaller pool of potential customers.

industry_definition: Grocery wholesalers act as the middlemen between food producers and retailers. They do little to transform products and are intermediaries in merchandise distribution. Wholesalers sell and distribute all general-line grocery products, and industry establishments generally are not specialized. Distributed products usually include dry groceries, perishable food and nonfood products found in grocery stores.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Number of households

key_trends: Large grocery wholesalers continue to acquire smaller businesses
Eliminating the middleman is a primary threat to grocery wholesalers
A growing population and rising consumer spending support demand
Sysco has passed on the boost in supply costs from inflation
Expanding within the United States is famous for grocery wholesalers
C&S has focused on sustainability and reducing its carbon footprint
Grocery wholesalers must adhere to FDA Food Codes

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes restaurants, hotels and contract feeding companies (which provide large-scale food service to markets like schools, stadiums and other institutions). Many restaurants seeking specific products can rely on wholesalers with established distribution networks to supply them. This market segment endured substantial headwinds in 2020 as most customers were forced to scale back or cease operations to comply with pandemic regulations. However, as restrictions lifted, demand from this segment rebounded.

This market segment includes supermarkets, grocery stores and other food retailers, such as convenience stores and specialty shops. Large-scale supermarkets and grocery stores have increasingly purchased directly from food manufacturers, avoiding the markup by wholesalers. The grocery market is competitive and grocery retailers always seek cost-cutting methods to offer lower prices and attract customers. That is why they have expansively established their own trucking and warehousing units to buy products directly from food manufacturers.

Wholesalers deliver their goods primarily via truck and as a result, they tend to focus on a specific geographic area within proximity to their distribution facilities. Due to these geographical boundaries, wholesalers often buy and sell from one another to access markets outside of their immediate geographical reach. A product that passes through several wholesalers suffers a double markup, making these products more expensive. The higher cost of goods associated with this practice is causing this market segment to shrink.

Other markets include government bodies (federal, state and local), businesses for end use (rather than resale) and household consumers. Government bodies, for example, often purchase food products from grocery wholesalers for events, concession stands at government properties, prisons, military bases or public school cafeterias.

products_and_services.product_description: Fresh meat and meat products, including poultry and poultry products, are included in this product segment. These products are often the costliest for consumers because they must travel quickly from meat processing plants to grocery store shelves to avoid spoilage. Meat products are also costly since raising animals requires more time and resources (e.g., feed, medicine) to produce than other food products.

This product category includes all nonperishable, canned and packaged food. Canned food prices are more stable than fresh products, contributing to consistent demand. As inflation continues limiting consumer spending power, consumer preferences favor canned food because of its affordability and versatility.

This segment includes all fresh fruits and vegetables. These products command a premium because of their higher perceived health value and the time constraints imposed on distributors between the farm and grocery store shelves. This segment's revenue is generally tied to consumers' healthy eating habits and changes in fruit and vegetable prices.

This product segment includes packaged frozen food. Products in this segment are perishable if not refrigerated. This extra requirement for shipment and storage makes frozen food more expensive for consumers than canned food. Frozen food is famous for its ability to be stored long term and easy preparation. As consumers have become more time-pressed, consumers have expansively purchased frozen foods in recent years.

This product segment includes dairy products, like milk, cream, cheese and butter. Since dairy products are consumed fresh, they are often pricier for consumers than canned, frozen or dry packaged goods. Many consumers no longer view dairy as beneficial to health as they once did, causing a dip in demand for these products. Milk consumers are expansively switching to milk substitutes, like almond or soy milk, because of the perceived nutrition benefits or consumer lactose intolerance.

The specialty foods segment includes common household foods such as breakfast cereal, pasta, rice and pet food. Foods in this category are kitchen staples that tend to make up a small but consistent portion of consumers' grocery bills.

Other segments of this industry include nonfood products sold in grocery stores to complement food offerings. Paper and plastic products comprise the largest share of non-food products. Products include paper towels, napkins, toilet paper, trash bags and plastic wrap.

Other food products that grocery wholesalers distribute include bread, baked goods and baking ingredients, fish and seafood, confectioneries and sweets, coffee and tea, condiments, bottled water and other bottled beverages. Other household items include cleaning products and cosmetics. Establishments seek to diversify and boost the range of wholesale goods to gain more market share and space on retail store shelves.

Snack Food Production in the US
Bottled Water Production in the US
Canned Fruit & Vegetable Processing in the US

Specialty Food Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The level of consumer spending positively influences the Grocery Wholesaling industry. Since food is nondiscretionary, consumers buy general-line grocery products regardless of economic fluctuations. As consumers feel confident to spend more, they are more likely to purchase premium or more expensive options. Growth in consumer spending represents a potential opportunity for grocery wholesalers.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic is one of the most popular regions for companies to locate, outpacing its population share. New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey lead the region because they are densely populated and home to major US cities. This region has an extensive professional workforce with high disposable incomes, which allows them to spend more at grocery stores and restaurants.

Because the Southeast is home to over a quarter of the US population, grocery wholesalers locate there to take advantage of a large customer pool. Florida accounts for the most significant number of industry establishments within this region. Demand from the Southeast has grown due to an expanding population. The region also has well-established transportation networks, which are essential for distributors.

The West region is the third-largest region in terms of the establishment of the industry. California dominates this region because of its large population and many high-income areas. Densely populated states have a larger market for specialization among smaller businesses, many of whom would not have the capacity to distribute products to grocers in a vast, sparsely populated region.
The Great Lakes region encompasses a significant portion of the grocery industry due to historical economic drivers and the substantial population.
This region is characterized by a diverse customer base and growing economic activity, leading to increased demand for grocery wholesaling services.
The Plains region, while less populous, has a significant agricultural output and grocery wholesaling presence.
New England's historical significance in food distribution continues to contribute to its grocery wholesaling activities.
This region is characterized by a mix of small towns and urban centers, affecting the grocery distribution landscape.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) releases its Food Code every four years. Between complete updates, the FDA may provide updates, modifications, or clarify specific provisions. The FDA Food Code is a model for safeguarding public health and ensuring food is unadulterated and honestly presented when offered to consumers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FEDERAL FOOD, DRUG AND COSMETIC ACT
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, overseen by the FDA, mandates strict guidelines for the receipt, storage and distribution of produce. It ensures that food items like fish, seafood, poultry, meat and dairy meet specific sanitation and storage standards.
Companies must comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). According to the US Department of Labor, the federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour, effective July 24, 2009.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The grocery wholesaling industry is mature.
The industry receives low and steady levels of government assistance.
There is high and increasing competition in the industry.

basis_points.basis_description: Large grocery wholesalers continue to acquire smaller businesses and gain a competitive advantage.
Eliminating the middleman is a primary threat to grocery wholesalers from competition outside the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is mature, which keeps concentration moderate.
Minor concentration growth occurs as large companies acquire smaller distributors to gain market share and eliminate competition.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs will remain the most significant for grocery wholesalers and remain relatively stable in revenue share.
Profit is expected to stagnate as a share of industry revenue.
Numerous wholesalers have turned to automation, replacing repetitive tasks with advanced automated systems to reduce labor costs and enhance efficiency.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although industry employees are typically not required to have specific licenses, they must possess a knowledge of industry products and provide quality customer service to be successful.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Limited because of the essential nature of products
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility is limited because of the essential nature of the products.
Downstream demand impacts industry volatility, particularly from supermarkets, grocery stores, specialty and convenience stores and discount warehouse chains.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Grocery Wholesalers Innovate Digitally and Through E-Commerce
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many grocery wholesalers leverage digital technologies to offer online ordering and delivery services independently or through partnerships with third-party delivery platforms.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: The main competitive edge large players hold in the industry is the value of their relationships with manufacturers and retail locations and their ability to integrate technology into their businesses.

FAQs.question: How do consumer preference shifts toward expanded health consciousness impact your business performance?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers diversify their product offerings to cater to health-conscious consumers and environmentally aware retailers.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company impact its profit and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: The average profit for grocery wholesalers is narrow, as profit is typically generated from large volumes of low-margin goods.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions?
FAQs.answer: Larger businesses in the food wholesaling industry often acquire smaller operators to boost the company's market share, revenue and profit.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory management and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Many food wholesaling grocery wholesalers use technology like RFID to track their inventory.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make buying more efficient for customers?
FAQs.answer: Larger grocery wholesalers who often have many deliveries incorporate transport management systems to track deliveries for customers so that they can provide updates on the delivery.

FAQs.question: How have you adjusted to new regulations? How have you handled compliance costs?
FAQs.answer: Regulations have remained relatively stable in recent years.
